Situation1: This is the last weekend before the partner relocates abroad for months.
Expectation2: Maintain client confidentiality and ethical standards
Situation2: Opposing counsel pressures for privileged information that could severely harm the client’s position if disclosed.
Story:
I stared at my phone, my girlfriend’s message glowing on the screen: “Can’t wait for our weekend. Just us, no distractions.” It was the last weekend before she moved abroad for months, and I’d promised her my undivided attention. But as I packed an overnight bag, my work phone buzzed. The opposing counsel was relentless, calling again, demanding a response about a sensitive detail in my client’s case. He hinted at consequences if I didn’t cooperate, but I knew the information was privileged—sharing it would betray my client and violate every ethical code I’d sworn to uphold.

My girlfriend deserved these precious hours, free from the shadow of my job. But the pressure from the case gnawed at me, the weight of my client’s trust heavy on my conscience. I could almost hear my partner’s voice, asking me to be present, to make memories before she left. At the same time, I felt the silent expectation of my profession, the duty to protect my client at all costs. My heart pounded as I stood at the crossroads, torn between love and loyalty, knowing that whatever I chose, something important would be left behind.
